text: IN THE LAND OF TIME
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thus Karnith, King of Alatta, spake to his eldest son: "I bequeath to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thee my city of Zoon, with its golden eaves, whereunder hum the bees.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I bequeath to thee also the land of Alatta, and all such other
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lands as thou art worthy to possess, for my three strong armies which I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leave thee may well take Zindara and over-run Istahn, and drive back
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Onin from his frontier, and leaguer the walls of Yan, and beyond that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spread conquest over the lesser lands of Hebith, Ebnon, and Karida.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Only lead not thine armies against Zeenar, nor ever cross the Eidis."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thereat in the city of Zoon in the land of Alatta, under his golden
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eaves, died King Karnith, and his soul went whither had gone the souls
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of his sires the elder Kings, and the souls of their slaves.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then Karnith Zo, the new King, took the iron crown of Alatta and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: afterwards went down to the plains that encircle Zoon and found his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: three strong armies clamouring to be led against Zeenar, over the river
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Eidis.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the new King came back from his armies, and all one night in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great palace alone with his iron crown, pondered long upon war; and a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little before dawn he saw dimly through his palace window, facing east
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over the city of Zoon and across the fields of Alatta, to far off where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a valley opened on Istahn. There, as he pondered, he saw the smoke
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: arising tall and straight over small houses in the plain and the fields
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where the sheep fed. Later the sun rose shining over Alatta as it shone
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over Istahn, and there arose a stir about the houses both in Alatta and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Istahn, and cocks crowded in the city and men went out into the fields
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among the bleating sheep; and the King wondered if men did otherwise in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Istahn. And men and women met as they went out to work and the sound of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: laughter arose from streets and fields; the King's eyes gazed into the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: distance toward Istahn and still the smoke went upward tall and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: straight from the small houses. And the sun rose higher that shone upon
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Alatta and Istahn, causing the flowers to open wide in each, and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: birds to sing and the voices of men and women to arise. And in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: market place of Zoon caravans were astir that set out to carry
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: merchandise to Istahn, and afterwards passed camels coming to Alatta
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with many tinkling bells. All this the King saw as he pondered much,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: who had not pondered before. Westward the Agnid mountains frowned in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the distance guarding the river Eidis; behind them the fierce people of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Zeenar lived in a bleak land.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Later the King, going abroad through his new kingdom, came on the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Temple of the gods of Old. There he found the roof shattered and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: marble columns broken and tall weeds met together in the inner shrine,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the gods of Old, bereft of worship or sacrifice, neglected and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forgotten. And the King asked of his councillors who it was that had
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: overturned this temple of the gods or caused the gods Themselves to be
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thus forsaken. And they answered him:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Time has done this."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Next the King came upon a man bent and crippled, whose face was
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: furrowed and worn, and the King having seen no such sight within the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: court of his father said to the man:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Who hath done this thing to you?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the old man answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Time hath ruthlessly done it."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the King and his councillors went on, and next they came upon a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: body of men carrying among them a hearse. And the King asked his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: councillors closely concerning death, for these things had not before
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: been expounded to the King. And the oldest of the councillors answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Death, O King, is a gift sent by the gods by the hand of their servant
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time, and some receive it gladly, and some are forced reluctantly to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: take it, and before others it is suddenly flung in the middle of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: day. And with this gift that Time hath brought him from the gods a man
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: must go forth into the dark to possess no other thing for so long as
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods are willing."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the King went back to his palace and gathered the greatest of his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophets and his councillors and asked them more particularly
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: concerning Time. And they told the King how that Time was a great
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: figure standing like a tall shadow in the dusk or striding, unseen,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: across the world, and how that he was the slave of the gods and did
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Their bidding, but ever chose new masters, and how all the former
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: masters of Time were dead and Their shrines forgotten. And one said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I have seen him once when I went down to play again in the garden of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: my childhood because of certain memories. And it was towards evening
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the light was pale, and I saw Time standing over the little gate,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pale like the light, and he stood between me and that garden and had
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stolen my memories because he was mightier than I."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And another said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I, too, have seen the Enemy of my House. For I saw him when he strode
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over the fields that I knew well and led a stranger by the hand to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: place him in my home to sit where my forefathers sat. And I saw him
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: afterwards walk thrice round the house and stoop and gather up the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glamour from the lawns and brush aside the tall poppies in the garden
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and spread weeds in his pathway where he strode through the remembered
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nooks."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And another said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "He went one day into the desert and brought up life out of the waste
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: places, and made it cry bitterly and covered it with the desert again."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And another said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I too saw him once seated in the garden of a child tearing the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flowers, and afterwards he went away through many woodlands and stooped
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down as he went, and picked the leaves one by one from the trees."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And another said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I saw him once by moonlight standing tall and black amidst the ruins
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of a shrine in the old kingdom of Amarna, doing a deed by night. And he
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wore a look on his face such as murderers wear as he busied himself to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cover over something with weeds and dust. Thereafter in Amarna the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people of that old Kingdom missed their god, in whose shrine I saw Time
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crouching in the night, and they have not since beheld him."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And all the while from the distance at the city's edge rose a hum from
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the three armies of the King clamouring to be led against Zeenar.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thereat the King went down to his three armies and speaking to their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chiefs said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I will not go down clad with murder to be King over other lands. I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have seen the same morning arising on Istahn that also gladdened
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Alatta, and have heard Peace lowing among the flowers. I will not
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: desolate homes to rule over an orphaned land and a land widowed. But I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will lead you against the pledged enemy of Alatta who shall crumble the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: towers of Zoon and hath gone far to overthrow our gods. He is the foe
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Zindara and Istahn and many-citadeled Yan, Hebith and Ebnon may not
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: overcome him nor Karida be safe against him among her bleakest
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountains. He is a foe mightier than Zeenar with frontiers stronger
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than Eidis; he leers at all the peoples of the earth and mocks their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods and covets their builded cities. Therefore we will go forth and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: conquer Time and save the gods of Alatta from his clutch, and coming
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: back victorious shall find that Death is gone and age and illness
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: departed, and here we shall live for ever by the golden eaves of Zoon,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: while the bees hum among unrusted gables and never crumbling towers.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There shall be neither fading nor forgetting, nor ever dying nor
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sorrow, when we shall have freed the people and pleasant fields of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth from inexorable Time."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the armies swore that they would follow the King to save the world
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the gods.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So the next day the King set forth with his three armies and crossed
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: many rivers and marched through many lands, and wherever they went they
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: asked for news of Time.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the first day they met a woman with her face furrowed and lined,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: who told them that she had been beautiful and that Time had smitten her
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the face with his five claws.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Many an old man they met as they marched in search of Time. All had
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seen him but none could tell them more, except that some said he went
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that way and pointed to a ruined tower or to an old and broken tree.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And day after day and month by month the King pushed on with his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: armies, hoping to come at last on Time. Sometimes they encamped at
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night near palaces of beautiful design or beside gardens of flowers,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hoping to find their enemy when he came to desecrate in the dark.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sometimes they came on cobwebs, sometimes on rusted chains and houses
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with broken roofs or crumbling walls. Then the armies would push on
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: apace thinking that they were closer upon the track of Time.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: As the weeks passed by and weeks grew to months, and always they heard
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: reports and rumours of Time, but never found him, the armies grew weary
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the great march, but the King pushed on and would let none turn
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: back, saying always that the enemy was near at hand.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Month in, month out, the King led on his now unwilling armies, till at
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: last they had marched for close upon a year and came to the village of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: deserted from his armies and settled down in Astarma and married
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Astarmian girls. By these soldiers we have the march of the armies
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: clearly chronicled to the time when they came to Astarma, having been
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nigh a year upon the march. And the army left that village and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: children cheered them as they went up the street, and five miles
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: distant they passed over a ridge of hills and out of sight. Beyond this
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tales that the veterans of the King's armies used to tell in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evenings about the fires in Zoon and remembered afterwards by the men
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Zeenar.

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went on past Astarma came at last (it is not known after how long a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shaped with quaint devices and overrun with weeds. On rusted hinges the
title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and passed the village. From one of his towers Time eyed them all the

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

text: them at Karnith Zo and at all his men. And the knees of the army

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his aged army that tottered down the slope.

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

text: tall along the outer walls, many a roof had fallen, gables were
title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

text: THE RELENTING OF SARNIDAC
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The lame boy Sarnidac tended sheep on a hill to the southward of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city. Sarnidac was a dwarf and greatly derided in the city. For the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: women said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "It is very funny that Sarnidac is a dwarf," and they would point their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fingers at him saying:--"This is Sarnidac, he is a dwarf; also he is
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: very lame."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Once the doors of all the temples in the world swung open to the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: morning, and Sarnidac with his sheep upon the hill saw strange figures
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: going down the white road, always southwards. All the morning he saw
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dust rising above the strange figures and always they went
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: southwards right as far as the rim of the Nydoon hills where the white
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: road could be seen no more. And the figures stooped and seemed to be
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: larger than men, but all men seemed very large to Sarnidac, and he
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: could not see clearly through the dust. And Sarnidac shouted to them,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as he hailed all people that passed down the long white road, and none
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the figures looked to left or right and none of them turned to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: answer Sarnidac. But then few people ever answered him because he was
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lame, and a small dwarf.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Still the figures went striding swiftly, stooping forward through the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dust, till at last Sarnidac came running down his hill to watch them
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: closer. As he came to the white road the last of the figures passed
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him, and Sarnidac ran limping behind him down the road.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: For Sarnidac was weary of the city wherein all derided him, and when he
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: saw these figures all hurrying away he thought that they went perhaps
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to some other city beyond the hills over which the sun shone brighter,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: or where there was more food, for he was poor, even perhaps where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people had not the custom of laughing at Sarnidac. So this procession
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of figures that stooped and seemed larger than men went southward down
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the road and a lame dwarf hobbled behind them.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Khamazan, now called the City of the Last of Temples, lies southward of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Nydoon hills. This is the story of Pompeides, now chief prophet of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the only temple in the world, and greatest of all the prophets that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have been:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: On the slopes of Nydoon I was seated once above Khamazan. There I saw
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: figures in the morning striding through much dust along the road that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leads across the world. Striding up the hill they came towards me, not
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the gait of men, and soon the first one came to the crest of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hill where the road dips to find the plains again, where lies Khamazan.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now I swear by all the gods that are gone that this thing happened
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as I shall say it, and was surely so. When those that came striding up
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hill came to its summit they took not the road that goes down into
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the plains nor trod the dust any longer, but went straight on and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upwards, striding as they strode before, as though the hill had not
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ended nor the road dipped. And they strode as though they trod no
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: yielding substance, yet they stepped upwards through the air.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: This the gods did, for They were not born men who strode that day so
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strangely away from earth.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But I, when I saw this thing, when already three had passed me, leaving
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth, cried out before the fourth:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Gods of my childhood, guardians of little homes, whither are ye going,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leaving the round earth to swim alone and forgotten in so great a waste
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of sky?'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And one answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Heresy apace shoots her fierce glare over the world and men's faith
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grows dim and the gods go. Men shall make iron gods and gods of steel
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when the wind and the ivy meet within the shrines of the temples of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods of old.'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I left that place as a man leaves fire by night, and going
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: plainwards down the white road that the gods spurned cried out to all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that I passed to follow me, and so crying came to the city's gates. And
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there I shouted to all near the gates:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'From yonder hilltop the gods are leaving earth.'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then I gathered many, and we all hastened to the hill to pray the gods
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to tarry, and there we cried out to the last of the departing gods:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Gods of old prophecy and of men's hopes, leave not the earth, and all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: our worship shall hum about Your ears as never it hath before, and oft
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sacrifice shall squeal upon Your altars.'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I said:--
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Gods of still evenings and quiet nights, go not from earth and leave
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not Your carven shrines, and all men shall worship You still. For
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: between us and yonder still blue spaces oft roam the thunder and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: storms, there in his hiding lurks the dark eclipse, and there are
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stored all snows and hails and lightnings that shall vex the earth for
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a million years. Gods of our hopes, how shall men's prayers crying from
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: empty shrines pass through such terrible spaces; how shall they ever
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fare above the thunder and many storms to whatever place the gods may
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: go in that blue waste beyond?'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the gods bent straight forward, and trampled through the sky and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: looked not to the right nor left nor downwards, nor ever heeded my
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prayer.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And one cried out hoping yet to stay the gods, though nearly all were
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gone, saying:--
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'O gods, rob not the earth of the dim hush that hangs round all Your
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: temples, bereave not all the world of old romance, take not the glamour
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the moonlight nor tear the wonder out of the white mists in every
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: land; for, O ye gods of the childhood of the world, when You have left
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the earth you shall have taken the mystery from the sea and all its
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glory from antiquity, and You shall have wrenched out hope from the dim
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: future. There shall be no strange cries at night time half understood,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nor songs in the twilight, and the whole of the wonder shall have died
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with last year's flowers in little gardens or hill-slopes leaning
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: south; for with the gods must go the enchantment of the plains and all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the magic of dark woods, and something shall be lacking from the quiet
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of early dawn. For it would scarce befit the gods to leave the earth
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and not take with Them that which They had given it. Out beyond the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: still blue spaces Ye will need the holiness of sunset for Yourselves
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and little sacred memories and the thrill that is in stories told by
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: firesides long ago. One strain of music, one song, one line of poetry
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and one kiss, and a memory of one pool with rushes, and each one the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: best, shall the gods take to whom the best belongs, when the gods go.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Sing a lamentation, people of Khamazan, sing a lamentation for all the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: children of earth at the feet of the departing gods. Sing a lamentation
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for the children of earth who now must carry their prayers to empty
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shrines and around empty shrines must rest at last.'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then when our prayers were ended and our tears shed, we beheld the last
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and smallest of the gods halted upon the hilltop. Twice he called to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Them with a cry somewhat like the cry wherewith our shepherds hail
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their brethren, and long gazed after Them, and then deigned to look no
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: longer and to tarry upon earth and turn his eyes on men. Then a great
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shout went up when we saw that our hopes were saved and that there was
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: still on earth a haven for our prayers. Smaller than men now seemed the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: figures that had loomed so big, as one behind the other far over our
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heads They still strode upwards. But the small god that had pitied the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: world came with us down the hill, still deigning to tread the road,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: though strangely, not as men tread, and into Khamazan. There we housed
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him in the palace of the King, for that was before the building of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: temple of gold, and the King made sacrifice before him with his own
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hands, and he that had pitied the world did eat the flesh of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sacrifice.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the Book of the Knowledge of the gods in Khamazan tells how the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: small god that pitied the world told his prophets that his name was
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sarnidac and that he herded sheep, and that therefore he is called the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shepherd god, and sheep are sacrificed upon his altars thrice a day,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the North, East, West and the South are the four hurdles of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sarnidac and the white clouds are his sheep. And the Book of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Knowledge of the gods tells further how the day on which Pompeides
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: found the gods shall be kept for ever as a fast until the evening and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: called the Fast of the Departing, but in the evening shall a feast be
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: held which is named the Feast of the Relenting, for on that evening
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sarnidac pitied the whole world and tarried.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the people of Khamazan all prayed to Sarnidac, and dreamed their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dreams and hoped their hopes because their temple was not empty.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Whether the gods that are departed be greater than Sarnidac none know
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in Khamazan, but some believe that in their azure windows They have set
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lights that lost prayers swarming upwards may come to them like moths
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and at last find haven and light far up above the evening and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stillness where sit the gods.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But Sarnidac wondered at the strange figures, at the people of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Khamazan, and at the palace of the King and the customs of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophets, but wondered not more greatly at aught in Khamazan than he
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had wondered at the city which he had left. For Sarnidac, who had not
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: known why men were unkind to him, thought that he had found at last the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: land for which the gods had let him hope, where men should have the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: custom of being kind to Sarnidac.

text: THE JEST OF THE GODS
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Once the Older gods had need of laughter. Therefore They made the soul
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of a king, and set in it ambitions greater than kings should have, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lust for territories beyond the lust of other kings, and in this soul
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They set strength beyond the strength of others and fierce desire for
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: power and a strong pride. Then the gods pointed earthward and sent that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: soul into the fields of men to live in the body of a slave. And the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slave grew, and the pride and lust for power began to arise in his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heart, and he wore shackles on his arms. Then in the Fields of Twilight
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods prepared to laugh.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the slave went down to the shore of the great sea, and cast his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: body away and the shackles that were upon it, and strode back to the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Fields of Twilight and stood up before the gods and looked Them in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Their faces. This thing the gods, when They had prepared to laugh, had
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not foreseen. Lust for power burned strong in that King's soul, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there was all the strength and pride in it that the gods had placed
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: therein, and he was too strong for the Older gods. He whose body had
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: borne the lashes of men could brook no longer the dominion of the gods,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and standing before Them he bade the gods to go. Up to Their lips leapt
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the anger of the Older gods, being for the first time commanded,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but the King's soul faced Them still, and Their anger died away and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They averted Their eyes. Then Their thrones became empty, and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Fields of Twilight bare as the gods slunk far away. But the soul chose
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: new companions.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE DREAMS OF THE PROPHET
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When the gods drave me forth to toil and assailed me with thirst and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beat me down with hunger, then I prayed to the gods. When the gods
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: smote the cities wherein I dwelt, and when Their anger scorched me and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Their eyes burned, then did I praise the gods and offer sacrifice. But
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when I came again to my green land and found that all was gone, and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old mysterious haunts wherein I prayed as a child were gone, and when
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods tore up the dust and even the spider's web from the last
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: remembered nook, then did I curse the gods, speaking it to Their faces,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: saying:--
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Gods of my prayers! Gods of my sacrifice! because Ye have forgotten
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sacred places of my childhood, and they have therefore ceased to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be, yet may I not forget. Because Ye have done this thing, Ye shall see
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cold altars and shall lack both my fear and praise. I shall not wince
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at Your lightnings, nor be awed when Ye go by."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then looking seawards I stood and cursed the gods, and at this moment
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there came to me one in the garb of a poet, who said:--
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Curse not the gods."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I said to him:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Wherefore should I not curse Those that have stolen my sacred places
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the night, and trodden down the gardens of my childhood?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he said "Come, and I will show thee." And I followed him to where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: two camels stood with their faces towards the desert. And we set out
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and I travelled with him for a great space, he speaking never a word,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and so we came at last to a waste valley hid in the desert's midst. And
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: herein, like fallen moons, I saw vast ribs that stood up white out of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sand, higher than the hills of the desert. And here and there lay
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the enormous shapes of skulls like the white marble domes of palaces
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: built for tyrannous kings a long while since by armies of driven
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slaves. Also there lay in the desert other bones, the bones of vast
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: legs and arms, against which the desert, like a besieging sea, ever
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: advanced and already had half drowned. And as I gazed in wonder at
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: these colossal things the poet said to me:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "The gods are dead."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I gazed long in silence, and I said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "These fingers, that are now so dead and so very white and still, tore
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: once the flowers in gardens of my youth."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But my companion said to me:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I have brought thee here to ask of thee thy forgiveness of the gods,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for I, being a poet, knew the gods, and would fain drive off the curses
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that hover above Their bones and bring Them men's forgiveness as an
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: offering at the last, that the weeds and the ivy may cover Their bones
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the sun."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "They made Remorse with his fur grey like a rainy evening in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: autumn, with many rending claws, and Pain with his hot hands and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lingering feet, and Fear like a rat with two cold teeth carved each out
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the ice of either pole, and Anger with the swift flight of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dragonfly in summer having burning eyes. I will not forgive these
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the poet said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Canst thou be angry with these beautiful white bones?" And I looked
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long at those curved and beautiful bones that were no longer able to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hurt the smallest creature in all the worlds that they had made. And I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thought long of the evil that they had done, and also of the good. But
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when I thought of Their great hands coming red and wet from battles to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: make a primrose for a child to pick, then I forgave the gods.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And a gentle rain came falling out of heaven and stilled the restless
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sand, and a soft green moss grew suddenly and covered the bones till
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they looked like strange green hills, and I heard a cry and awoke and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: found that I had dreamed, and looking out of my house into the street I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: found that a flash of lightning had killed a child. Then I knew that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods still lived.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: _II_
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I lay asleep in the poppy fields of the gods in the valley of Alderon,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where the gods come by night to meet together in council when the moon
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is low. And I dreamed that this was the Secret.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Fate and Chance had played their game and ended, and all was over, all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hopes and tears, regrets, desires and sorrows, things that men wept
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for and unremembered things, and kingdoms and little gardens and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sea, and the worlds and the moons and the suns; and what remained was
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nothing, having neither colour nor sound.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said Fate to Chance: "Let us play our old game again." And they
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: played it again together, using the gods as pieces, as they had played
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it oft before. So that those things which have been shall all be again,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and under the same bank in the same land a sudden glare of singlight on
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the same spring day shall bring the same daffodil to bloom once more
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the same child shall pick it, and not regretted shall be the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: billion years that fell between. And the same old faces shall be seen
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again, yet not bereaved of their familiar haunts. And you and I shall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in a garden meet again upon an afternoon in summer when the sun stands
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: midway between his zenith and the sea, where we met oft before. For
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Fate and Chance play but one game together with every move the same,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and they play it oft to while eternity away.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: PART II.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE JOURNEY OF THE KING
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: One day the King turned to the women that danced and said to them:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Dance no more," and those that bore the wine in jewelled cups he sent
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: away. The palace of King Ebalon was emptied of sound of song and there
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rose the voices of heralds crying in the streets to find the prophets
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the land.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then went the dancers, the cupbearer and the singers down into the hard
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets among the houses, Pattering Leaves, Silvern Fountain and Summer
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Lightning, the dancers whose feet the gods had not devised for stony
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ways, which had only danced for princes. And with them went the singer,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Soul of the South, and the sweet singer, Dream of the Sea, whose voices
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods had attuned to the ears of kings, and old Istahn the cupbearer
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: left his life's work in the palace to tread the common ways, he that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had stood at the elbows of three kings of Zarkandhu and had watched his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ancient vintage feeding their valour and mirth as the waters of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Tondaris feed the green plains to the south. Ever he had stood grave
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among their jests, but his heart warmed itself solely by the fire of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mirth of Kings. He too, with the singers and dancers, went out into
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dark.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And throughout the land the heralds sought out the prophets thereof.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then one evening as King Ebalon sat alone within his palace there were
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brought before him all who had repute for wisdom and who wrote the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: histories of the times to be. Then the King spake, saying: "The King
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: goeth upon a journey with many horses, yet riding upon none, when the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pomp of travelling shall be heard in the streets and the sound of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lute and the drum and the name of the King. And I would know what
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: princes and what people shall greet me on the other shore in the land
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to which I travel."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then fell a hush upon the prophets for they murmured: "All knowledge is
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the King."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said the King: "Thou first, Samahn, High Prophet of the Temple of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gold in Azinorn, answer or thou shalt write no more the history of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: times to be, but shalt toil with thy hand to make record of the little
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: happenings of the days that were, as do the common men."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said Samahn: "All knowledge is with the King," and when the pomp of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: travelling shall be heard in the streets and the slow horses whereon
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the King rideth not go behind lute and drum, then, as the King well
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: knoweth, thou shalt go down to the great white house of Kings and,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: entering the portals where none are worthy to follow, shalt make
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: obeisance alone to all the elder Kings of Zarkandhu, whose bones are
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seated upon golden thrones grasping their sceptres still. Therein thou
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shalt go with robes and sceptre through the marble porch, but thou
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shalt leave behind thee thy gleaming crown that others may wear it, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as the times go by come in to swell the number of the thirty Kings that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sit in the great white house on golden thrones. There is one doorway in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the great white house, and it stands wide with marble portals yawning
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for kings, but when it shall receive thee, and thine obeisance hath
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: been made because of thine obligation to the thirty Kings, thou shalt
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: find at the back of the house an unknown door through which the soul of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a King may just pass, and leaving thy bones upon a golden throne thou
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shalt go unseen out of the great white house to tread the velvet spaces
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that lie among the worlds. Then, O King, it were well to travel fast
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and not to tarry about the houses of men as do the souls of some who
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: still bewail the sudden murder that sent them upon the journey before
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their time, and who, being yet both to go, linger in dark chambers all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the night. These, setting forth to travel in the dawn and travelling
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the day, see earth behind them gleaming when an evening falls, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again are loth to leave its pleasant haunts, and come back again
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through dark woods and up into some old loved chamber, and ever tarry
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: between home and flight and find no rest.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thou wilt set forth at once because the journey is far and lasts for
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: many hours; but the hours on the velvet spaces are the hours of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods, and we may not say what time such an hour may be if reckoned in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mortal years.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: At last thou shalt come to a grey place filled with mist, with grey
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shapes standing before it which are altars, and on the altars rise
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: small red flames from dying fires that scarce illumine the mist. And in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mist it is dark and cold because the fires are low. These are the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: altars of the people's faiths, and the flames are the worship of men,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and through the mist the gods of Old go groping in the dark and in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cold. There thou shalt hear a voice cry feebly: "Inyani, Inyani, lord
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the thunder, where art thou, for I cannot see?" And a voice shall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: answer faintly in the cold: "O maker of many worlds, I am here." And in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that place the gods of Old are nearly deaf for the prayers of men grow
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: few, they are nigh blind because the fires burn low upon the altars of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men's faiths and they are very cold. And all about the place of mist
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there lies a moaning sea which is called the Sea of Souls. And behind
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the place of mist are the dim shapes of mountains, and on the peak of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one there glows a silvern light that shines in the moaning sea; and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ever as the flames on the altars die before the gods of Old the light
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on the mountain increases, and the light shines over the mist and never
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through it as the gods of Old grow blind. It is said that the light on
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the mountain shall one day become a new god who is not of the gods of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Old.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There, O King, thou shalt enter the Sea of Souls by the shore where the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: altars stand which are covered in mist. In that sea are the souls of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all that ever lived on the worlds and all that ever shall live, all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: freed from earth and flesh. And all the souls in that sea are aware of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one another but more than with hearing or sight or by taste or touch or
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: smell, and they all speak to each other yet not with lips, with voices
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: which need no sound. And over the sea lies music as winds o'er an ocean
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on earth, and there unfettered by language great thoughts set outward
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through the souls as on earth the currents go.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Once did I dream that in a mist-built ship I sailed upon that sea and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heard the music that is not of instruments, and voices not from lips,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and woke and found that I was upon the earth and that the gods had lied
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to me in the night. Into this sea from fields of battle and cities come
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down the rivers of lives, and ever the gods have taken onyx cups and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: far and wide into the worlds again have flung the souls out of the sea,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that each soul may find a prison in the body of a man with five small
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: windows closely barred, and each one shackled with forgetfulness.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But all the while the light on the mountain grows, and none may say
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: what work the god that shall be born of the silvern light shall work on
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Sea of Souls, when the gods of Old are dead and the Sea is living
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: still.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And answer made the King:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Thou that art a prophet of the gods of Old, go back and see that those
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: red flames burn more brightly on the altars in the mist, for the gods
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Old are easy and pleasant gods, and thou canst not say what toil
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shall vex our souls when the god of the light on the mountain shall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stride along the shore where bleach the huge bones of the gods of Old."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Samahn answered: "All knowledge is with the King."

text: _II_
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the King called to Ynath bidding him speak concerning the journey
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the King. Ynath was the prophet that sat at the Eastern gate of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Temple of Gorandhu. There Ynath prayed his prayers to all the passers
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by lest ever the gods should go abroad, and one should pass him dressed
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in mortal guise. And men are pleased as they walk by that Eastern gate
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that Ynath should pray to them for fear that they be gods, so men bring
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gifts to Ynath in the Eastern gate.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Ynath said: "All knowledge is with the King. When a strange ship
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: comes to anchor in the air outside thy chamber window, thou shalt leave
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thy well-kept garden and it shall become a prey to the nights and days
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and be covered again with grass. But going aboard thou shalt set sail
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over the Sea of Time and well shall the ship steer through the many
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: worlds and still sail on. If other ships shall pass thee on the way and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hail thee saying: 'From what port' thou shalt answer them: 'From
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Earth.' And if they ask thee 'whither bound?' then thou shalt answer:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'The End.' Or thou shalt hail them saying: 'From what port?' And they
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shall answer: 'From The End called also The Beginning, and bound to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Earth.' And thou shalt sail away till like an old sorrow dimly felt by
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: happy men the worlds shall gleam in the distance like one star, and as
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the star pales thou shalt come to the shore of space where aeons
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rolling shorewards from Time's sea shall lash up centuries to foam away
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in years. There lies the Centre Garden of the gods, facing full
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seawards. All around lie songs that on earth were never sung, fair
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thoughts not heard among the worlds, dream pictures never seen that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: drifted over Time without a home till at last the aeons swept them on
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the shore of space. And in the Centre Garden of the gods bloom many
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fancies. Therein once some souls were playing where the gods walked up
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and down and to and fro. And a dream came in more beauteous than the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rest on the crest of a wave of Time, and one soul going downward to the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shore clutched at the dream and caught it. Then over the dreams and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stories and old songs that lay on the shore of space the hours came
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sweeping back, and the centuries caught that soul and swirled him with
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his dream far out to the Sea of Time, and the aeons swept him
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earthwards and cast him into a palace with all the might of the sea and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: left him there with his dream. The child grew to a King and still
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: clutched at his dream till the people wondered and laughed. Then, O
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King, Thou didst cast thy dream back into the Sea, and Time drowned it
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and men laughed no more, but thou didst forget that a certain sea beat
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on a distant shore and that there was a garden and therein souls. But
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at the end of the journey that thou shalt take, when thou comest to the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shore of space again thou shalt go up the beach, and coming to a garden
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gate that stands in a garden wall shalt remember these things again,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for it stands where the hours assail not above the beating of Time, far
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up the shore, and nothing altereth there. So thou shalt go through the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: garden gate and hear again the whispering of the souls when they talk
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: low where sing the voices of the gods. There with kindred souls thou

text: _III_
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then spake Monith, Prophet of the Temple of Azure that stands on the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: snow-peak of Ahmoon and said: "All knowledge is with the King. Once
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thou didst set out upon a one day's journey riding thy horse and before
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thee had gone a beggar down the road, and his name was Yeb. Him thou
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: didst overtake and when he heeded not thy coming thou didst ride over
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Upon the journey that thou shalt one day take riding upon no horse,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: this beggar has set out before thee and is labouring up the crystal
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: steps towards the moon as a man goeth up the steps of a high tower in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dark. On the moon's edge beneath the shadow of Mount Angises he
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shall rest awhile and then shall climb the crystal steps again. Then a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great journey lies before him before he may rest again till he come to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that star that is called the left eye of Gundo. Then a journey of many
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crystal steps lieth before him again with nought to guide him but the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: light of Omrazu. On the edge of Omrazu shall Yeb tarry long, for the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: most dreadful part of his journey lieth before him. Up the crystal
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: steps that lie beyond Omrazu he must go, and any that follow, though
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the howling of all the meteors that ride the sky; for in that part of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the crystal space go many meteors up and down all squealing in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dark, which greatly perplex all travellers. And, if he may see though
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gleaming of the meteors and in spite of their uproar come safely
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through, he shall come to the star Omrund at the edge of the Track of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Stars. And from star to star along the Track of Stars the soul of a man
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: may travel with more ease, and there the journey lies no more straight
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forward, but curves to the right."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said King Ebalon:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Of this beggar whom my horse smote down thou hast spoken much, but I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sought to know by what road a King should go when he taketh his last
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: royal journey, and what princes and what people should meet him upon
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: another shore."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then answered Monith:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "All knowledge is with the King. It hath been doomed by the gods, who
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: speak not in jest, that thou shalt follow the soul that thou didst send
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alone upon its journey, that that soul go not unattended up the crystal
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: steps.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Moreover, as this beggar went upon his lonely journey he dared to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: curse the King, and his curses lie like a red mist along the valleys
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and hollows wherever he uttered them. By these red mists, O King, thou
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shalt track him as a man follows a river by night until thou shalt fare
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at last to the land wherein he hath blessed thee (repenting of anger at
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: last), and thou shalt see his blessing lie over the land like a blaze
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of golden sunshine illumining fields and gardens."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said the King:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "The gods have spoken hard above the snowy peak of this mountain
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Ahmoon."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Monith said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "How a man may come to the shore of space beyond the tides of time I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: know not, but it is doomed that thou shalt certainly first follow the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beggar past the moon, Omrund and Omrazu till thou comest to the Track
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Stars, and up the Track of Stars coming towards the right along the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: edge of it till thou comest to Ingazi. There the soul of the beggar Yeb
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sat long, then, breathing deep, set off on his great journey earthward
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: adown the crystal steps. Straight through the spaces where no stars are
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: found to rest at, following the dull gleam of earth and her fields till
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he come at last where journeys end and start."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said King Ebalon:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "If this hard tale be true, how shall I find the beggar that I must
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: follow when I come again to the earth?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the Prophet answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Thou shalt know him by his name and find him in this place, for that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beggar shall be called King Ebalon and he shall be sitting upon the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: throne of the Kings of Zarkandhu."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the King answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "If one sit upon this throne whom men call King Ebalon, who then shall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I be?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the Prophet answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Thou shalt be a beggar and thy name shall be Yeb, and thou shalt ever
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tread the road before the palace waiting for alms from the King whom
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men shall call Ebalon."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said the King:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Hard gods indeed are those that tramp the snows of Ahmoon about the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: temple of Azure, for if I sinned against this beggar called Yeb, they
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: too have sinned against him when they doomed him to travel on this
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: weary journey though he hath not offended."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Monith said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "He too hath offended, for he was angry as thy horse struck him, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods smite anger. And his anger and his curses doom him to journey
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: without rest as also they doom thee."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said the King:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Thou that sittest upon Ahmoon in the Temple of Azure, dreaming thy
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dreams and making prophecies, foresee the ending of this weary quest
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and tell me where it shall be?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Monith answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "As a man looks across great lakes I have gazed into the days to be,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and as the great flies come upon four wings of gauze to skim over blue
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: waters, so have my dreams come sailing two by two out of the days to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be. And I dreamed that King Ebalon, whose soul was not thy soul, stood
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in his palace in a time far hence, and beggars thronged the street
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: outside, and among them was Yeb, a beggar, having thy soul. And it was
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on the morning of a festival and the King came robed in white, with all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his prophets and his seers and magicians, all down the marble steps to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bless the land and all that stood therein as far as the purple hills,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: because it was the morning of festival. And as the King raised up his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hand over the beggars' heads to bless the fields and rivers and all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that stood therein, I dreamed that the quest was ended.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "All knowledge is with the King."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: _IV_
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whereon haply others missed the secret too.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

text: prophets.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods. Therefore it is said in all those lands that Ynar speaks at
title: Time and the Gods

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "All knowledge is with the King, and without doubt it hath come to the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

text: Amanath.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city through whose streets Death walketh not, and I have heard it from
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord
