title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hills shall slip away, the dark woods, the sky and all the gleaming
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: worlds that fill the night, and the green fields shall go on untrodden
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by thy feet and the blue sky ungazed at by thine eyes, and still the
title: Time and the Gods

text: rivers shall all run seaward but making no music in thine ears. And all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the old laments shall still be spoken, troubling thee not, and to the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth shall fall the tears of the children of earth and never grieving
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thee. Pestilence, heat and cold, ignorance, famine and anger, these
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: things shall grip their claws upon all men as heretofore in fields and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: roads and cities but shall not hold thee. But from thy soul, sitting in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the old worn track of the worlds when all is gone away, shall fall off
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the shackles of circumstance and thou shalt dream thy dreams alone.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as the Rim but only thy dreams and thee.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: having no place in time, not to be assailed by the hours or harmed by
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ivy or rust, not to be taken by conquerors, but destroyed by thy fancy
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: if thou dost wish it so or by thy fancy rebuilded. And nought shall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ever disturb these dreams of thine which here are troubled and lost by
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the happenings of earth, as the dreams of one who sleeps in a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tumultuous city. For these thy dreams shall sweep outward like a strong
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: river over a great waste plain wherein are neither rocks nor hills to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: turn it, only in that place there shall be no boundaries nor sea,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: neither hindrance nor end. And it were well for thee that thou shouldst
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: take few regrets into thy waste dominions from the world wherein thou
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: livest, for such regrets or any memory of deeds ill done must sit
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beside thy soul forever in that waste, singing one song always of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forlorn remorse; and they too shall be only dreams but very real.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "There nought shall hinder thee among thy dreams, for even the gods may
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

text: bound thee shall have slipped away."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said the King:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I like not this grey doom, for dreams are empty. I would see action
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: roaring through the world, and men and deeds."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then answered the Prophet:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Victory, jewels and dancing but please thy fancy. What is the sparkle
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the gem to thee without thy fancy which it allures, and thy fancy is
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all a dream. Action and deeds and men are nought without dreams and do
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but fetter them, and only dreams are real, and where thou stayest when
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the worlds shall drift away there shall be only dreams."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the King answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "A mad prophet."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Ynar said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "A mad prophet, but believing that his soul possesseth all things of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: which his soul may become aware and that he is master of that soul, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thou a high-minded King believing only that thy soul possesseth such
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: few countries as are leaguered by thine armies and the sea, and that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: who shall deal with it in a way whereof thou knowest not. Until a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: knowledge come to us that either is wrong I have wider realms, I King,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than thee and hold them beneath no overlords."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Thou hast said no overlords! To whom then dost thou speak by strange
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: signs at evening above the world?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Seize ye this prophet for he is a hypocrite and speaks to no gods at
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening above the world, but has deceived us with his signs."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Ynar said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Come not near me or I shall point towards you when I speak at evening
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon the mountain with Those that ye know of."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then Ynar went away and the guards touched him not.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then spake the prophet Thun, who was clad in seaweed and had no Temple,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but lived apart from men. All his life he had lived on a lonely beach
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and had heard for ever the wailing of the sea and the crying of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind in hollows among the cliffs. Some said that having lived so long
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by the full beating of the sea, and where always the wind cries
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: loudest, he could not feel the joys of other men, but only felt the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sorrow of the sea crying in his soul for ever.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Long ago on the path of stars, midmost between the worlds, there
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strode the gods of Old. In the bleak middle of the worlds They sat and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the worlds went round and round, like dead leaves in the wind at
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Autumn's end, with never a life on one, while the gods went sighing for
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the things that might not be. And the centuries went over the gods to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: go where the centuries go, toward the End of Things, and with Them went
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sighs of all the gods as They longed for what might not be.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "One by one in the midst of the worlds, fell dead the gods of Old,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: still sighing for the things that might not be, all slain by Their own
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: regrets. Only Shimono Kani, the youngest of the gods, made him a harp
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out of the heart strings of all the elder gods, and, sitting upon the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods of Old. And the song told of all vain regrets and of unhappy
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: loves of the gods in the olden time, and of Their great deeds that were
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to adorn the future years. But into the dirge of Shimono Kani came
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: voices crying out of the heart strings of the gods, all sighing still
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for the things that might not be. And the dirge and the voices crying,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: go drifting away from the Path of Stars, away from the Midst of Things,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: till they come twittering among the Worlds, like a great host of birds
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that are lost by night. And every note is a life, and many notes become
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: caught up among the worlds to be entangled with flesh for a little
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: while before they pass again on their journey to the great Anthem that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: roars at the End of Time. Shimono Kani hath given a voice to the wind
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and added a sorrow to the sea. But when in lighted chambers after
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sitting by his dead brethren, the elder gods, playing on the harp of
title: Time and the Gods

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Time and the Gods

title: Time and the Gods

text: cry and sendeth it out into the dark.

title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as there sometimes clings to a prisoner's feet some dust of the fields
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wherein he was captured, so sometimes fragments of remembrance cling to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a man's soul after it hath been taken to earth. Then a great minstrel
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: arises, and, weaving together the shreds of his memories, maketh some
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: melody such as the hand of Shimono Kani smites out of his harp; and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they that pass by say: 'Hath there not been some such melody before?'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and pass on sad at heart for memories which are not.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Therefore, O King, one day the great gates of thy palace shall lie
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: open for a procession wherein the King comes down to pass through a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people, lamenting with lute and drum; and on the same day a prison door
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shall be opened by relenting hands, and one more lost note of Shimono
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Kani's dirge shall go back to swell his melody again.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "The dirge of Shimono Kani shall roll on till one day it shall come
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with all its notes complete to overwhelm the Silence that sits at the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: End of Things. Then shall Shimono Kani say to his brethren's bones: The
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: things that might not be have at last become.'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "But very quiet shall be the bones of the gods of Old, and only Their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: voices shall live which cried from the harp of heart strings, for the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: things which might not be."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: _VI_
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When the caravans, saying farewell to Zandara, set out across the waste
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: northwards towards Einandhu, they follow the desert track for seven
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: days before they come to water where Shubah Onath rises black out of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the waste, with a well at its foot and herbage on its summit. On this
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rock a prophet hath his Temple and is called the Prophet of Journeys,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and hath carven in a southern window smiling along the camel track all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods that are benignant to caravans.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There a traveller may learn by prophecy whether he shall accomplish the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ten days' journey thence across the desert and so come to the white
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: city of Einandhu, or whether his bones shall lie with the bones of old
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: along the desert track.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: No name hath the Prophet of Journeys, for none is needed in that desert
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where no man calls nor ever a man answers.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Thus spake the Prophet of Journeys standing before the King:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "The journey of the King shall be an old journey pushed on apace.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Many a year before the making of the moon thou camest down with dream
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: camels from the City without a name that stands beyond all the stars.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And then began thy journey over the Waste of Nought, and thy dream
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: camel bore thee well when those of certain of thy fellow travellers
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fell down in the Waste and were covered over by the silence and were
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: turned again to nought; and those travellers when their dream camels
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fell, having nothing to carry them further over the Waste, were lost
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beyond and never found the earth. These are those men that might have
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: been but were not. And all about thee fluttered the myriad hours
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: travelling in great swarms across the Waste of Nought.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "How many centuries passed across the cities while thou wast making thy
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: journey none may reckon, for there is no time in the Waste of Nought,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but only the hours fluttering earthwards from beyond to do the work of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Time. At last the dream-borne travellers saw far off a green place
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gleaming and made haste towards it and so came to Earth. And there, O
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King, ye rest for a little while, thou and those that came with thee,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: making an encampment upon earth before journeying on. There the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: swarming hours alight, settling on every blade of grass and tree, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spreading over your tents and devouring all things, and at last bending
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: your very tent poles with their weight and wearying you.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Behind the encampment in the shadow of the tents lurks a dark figure
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with a nimble sword, having the name of Time. This is he that hath
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: called the hours from beyond and he it is that is their master, and it
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is his work that the hours do as they devour all green things upon the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth and tatter the tents and weary all the travellers. As each of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hours does the work of Time, Time smites him with his nimble sword as
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: soon as his work is done, and the hour falls severed to the dust with
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his bright wings scattered, as a locust cut asunder by the scimitar of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a skillful swordsman.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "One by one, O King, with a stir in the camp, and the folding up of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tents one by one, the travellers shall push on again on the journey
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: begun so long before out of the City without a name to the place where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dream camels go, striding free through the Waste. So into the Waste, O
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King, thou shalt set forth ere long, perhaps to renew friendships begun
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: during thy short encampment upon earth.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Other green places thou shalt meet in the Waste and thereon shalt
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: encamp again until driven thence by the hours. What prophet shall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: relate how many journeys thou shalt make or how many encampments? But
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: at last thou shalt come to the place of The Resting of Camels, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there shall gleaming cliffs that are named The Ending of Journeys lift
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up out of the Waste of Nought, Nought at their feet, Nought laying wide
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: before them, with only the glint of worlds far off to illumine the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Waste. One by one, on tired dream camels, the travellers shall come in,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and going up the pathway through the cliff in that land of The Resting
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Camels shall come on The City of Ceasing. There, the dream-wrought
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pinnacles and the spires that are builded of men's hopes shall rise up
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: real before thee, seen only hitherto as a mirage in the Waste.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "So far the swarming hours may not come, and far away among the tents
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shall stand the dark figure with the nimble sword. But in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: scintillant streets, under the song-built abodes of the last of cities,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thy journey, O King, shall end."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: _VII_
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: In the valley beyond Sidono there lies a garden of poppies, and where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the poppies' heads are all a-swing with summer breezes that go up the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valley there lies a path well strewn with ocean shells. Over Sidono's
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: summit the birds come streaming to the lake that lies in the valley of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the garden, and behind them rises the sun sending Sidono's shadow as
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: far as the edge of the lake. And down the path of many ocean shells
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when they begin to gleam in the sun, every morning walks an aged man
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: clad in a silken robe with strange devices woven. A little temple where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the old man lives stands at the edge of the path. None worship there,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for Zornadhu, the old prophet, hath forsaken men to walk among his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: poppies.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: For Zornadhu hath failed to understand the purport of Kings and cities
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the moving up and down of many people to the tune of the clinking
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of gold. Therefore hath Zornadhu gone far away from the sound of cities
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and from those that are ensnared thereby, and beyond Sidono's mountain
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hath come to rest where there are neither kings nor armies nor
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bartering for gold, but only the heads of the poppies that sway in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind together and the birds that fly from Sidono to the lake, and then
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sunrise over Sidono's summit; and afterwards the flight of birds
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out of the lake and over Sidono again, and sunset behind the valley,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and high over lake and garden the stars that know not cities. There
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Zornadhu lives in his garden of poppies with Sidono standing between
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him and the whole world of men; and when the wind blowing athwart the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valley sways the heads of the tall poppies against the Temple wall, the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old prophet says: "The flowers are all praying, and lo! they be nearer
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the gods than men."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But the heralds of the King coming after many days of travel to Sidono
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: perceived the garden valley. By the lake they saw the poppy garden
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gleaming round and small like a sunrise over water on a misty morning
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seen by some shepherd from the hills. And descending the bare mountain
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for three days they came to the gaunt pines, and ever between the tall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: trunks came the glare of the poppies that shone from the garden valley.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: For a whole day they travelled through the pines. That night a cold
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wind came up the garden valley crying against the poppies. Low in his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Temple, with a song of exceeding grief, Zornadhu in the morning made a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dirge for the passing of poppies, because in the night time there had
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fallen petals that might not return or ever come again into the garden
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valley. Outside the Temple on the path of ocean shells the heralds
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: halted, and read the names and honours of the King; and from the Temple
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came the voice of Zornadhu still singing his lament. But they took him
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from his garden because of the King's command, and down his gleaming
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: path of ocean shells and away up Sidono, and left the Temple empty with
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: none to lament when silken poppies died. And the will of the wind of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the autumn was wrought upon the poppies, and the heads of the poppies
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that rose from the earth went down to the earth again, as the plume of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a warrior smitten in a heathen fight far away, where there are none to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lament him. Thus out of his land of flowers went Zornadhu and came
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: perforce into the lands of men, and saw cities, and in the city's midst
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stood up before the King.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the King said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Zornadhu, what of the journey of the King and of the princes and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people that shall meet me?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Zornadhu answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I know nought of Kings, but in the night time the poppy made his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: journey a little before dawn. Thereafter the wildfowl came as is their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wont over Sidono's summit, and the sun rising behind them gleamed upon
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sidono, and all the flowers of the lake awoke. And the bee passing up
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and down the garden went droning to other poppies, and the flowers of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the lake, they that had known the poppy, knew him no more. And the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sun's rays slanting from Sidono's crest lit still a garden valley where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one poppy waved his petals to the dawn no more. And I, O King, that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down a path of gleaming ocean shells walk in the morning, found not,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nor have since found, that poppy again, that hath gone on the journey
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whence there is not returning, out of my garden valley. And I, O King,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: made a dirge to cry beyond that valley and the poppies bowed their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heads; but there is no cry nor no lament that may adjure the life to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: return again to a flower that grew in a garden once and hereafter is
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Unto what place the lives of poppies have gone no man shall truly say.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sure it is that to that place are only outward tracks. Only it may be
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that when a man dreams at evening in a garden where heavily the scent
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of poppies hangs in the air, when the winds have sunk, and far away the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sound of a lute is heard on lonely hills, as he dreams of silken-scarlet
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: poppies that once were a-swing together in the gardens of his youth, the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lives of those old lost poppies shall return, living again in his dream.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: *So there may dream the gods.* And through the dreams of some divinity
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: reclining in tinted fields above the morning we may haply pass again,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: although our bodies have long swirled up and down the world with other
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dust. In these strange dreams our lives may be again, all in the centre
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of our hopes, rejoicings and laments, until above the morning the gods
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wake to go about their work, haply to remember still Their idle dreams,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: haply to dream them all again in the stillness when shines the starlight
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the gods."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: _VIII_
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said the King: "I like not these strange journeys nor this faint
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wandering through the dreams of gods like the shadow of a weary camel
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that may not rest when the sun is low. The gods that have made me to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: love the earth's cool woods and dancing streams do ill to send me into
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the starry spaces that I love not, with my soul still peering earthward
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through the eternal years, as a beggar who once was noble staring from
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the street at lighted halls. For wherever the gods may send me I shall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be as the gods have made me, a creature loving the green fields of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Now if there stand one prophet here that hath the ear of those too
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: splendid gods that stride above the glories of the orient sky, tell
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them that there is on earth one King in the land called Zarkandhu to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the south of the opal mountains, who would fain tarry among the many
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gardens of earth, and would leave to other men the splendours that the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods shall give the dead above the twilight that surrounds the stars."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then spake Yamen, prophet of the Temple of Obin that stands on the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shores of a great lake, facing east. Yamen said: "I pray oft to the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods who sit above the twilight behind the east. When the clouds are
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heavy and red at sunset, or when there is boding of thunder or eclipse,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: then I pray not, lest my prayers be scattered and beaten earthward. But
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: when the sun sets in a tranquil sky, pale green or azure, and the light
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of his farewells stays long upon lonely hills, then I send forth my
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prayers to flutter upward to gods that are surely smiling, and the gods
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hear my prayers. But, O King, boons sought out of due time from the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods are never wholly to be desired, and, if They should grant to thee
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to tarry on the earth, old age would trouble thee with burdens more and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more till thou wouldst become the driven slave of the hours in fetters
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that none may break."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The King said: "They that have devised this burden of age may surely
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stay it, pray therefore on the calmest evening of the year to the gods
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: above the twilight that I may tarry always on the earth and always
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: young, while over my head the scourges of the gods pass and alight
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then answered Yamen: "The King hath commanded, yet among the blessings
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the gods there always cries a curse. The great princes that make merry
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the King, who tell of the great deeds that the King wrought in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: former time, shall one by one grow old. And thou, O King, seated at the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: feast crying, 'make merry' and extolling the former time shall find about
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thee white heads nodding in sleep, and men that are forgetting the former
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: time. Then one by one the names of those that sported with thee once
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: called by the gods, one by one the names of the singers that sing the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: songs thou lovest called by the gods, lastly of those that chased the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grey boar by night and took him in Orghoom river--only the King. Then
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a new people that have not known the old deeds of the King nor fought and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chased with him, who dare not make merry with the King as did his long
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dead princes. And all the while those princes that are dead growing dearer
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and greater in thy memory, and all the while the men that served thee then
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: growing more small to thee. And all the old things fading and new things
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: arising which are not as the old things were, the world changing yearly
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: before thine eyes and the gardens of thy childhood overgrown. Because thy
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: childhood was in the olden years thou shalt love the olden years, but ever
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the new years shall overthrow them and their customs, and not the will of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a King may stay the changes that the gods have planned for all the customs
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of old. Ever thou shalt say 'This was not so,' and ever the new custom
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shall prevail even against a King. When thou hast made merry a thousand
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: times thou shalt grow tired of making merry. At last thou shalt become
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: weary of the chase, and still old age shall not come near to thee to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stifle desires that have been too oft fulfilled; then, O King, thou shalt
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be a hunter yearning for the chase but with nought to pursue that hath
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not been oft overcome. Old age shall come not to bury thine ambitions in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a time when there is nought for thee to aspire to any more. Experience
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of many centuries shall make thee wise but hard and very sad, and thou
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shalt be a mind apart from thy fellows and curse them all for fools,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and they shall not perceive thy wisdom because thy thoughts are not
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their thoughts and the gods that they have made are not the gods of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: olden time. No solace shall thy wisdom bring thee but only an increasing
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: knowledge that thou knowest nought, and thou shalt feel as a wise man
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in a world of fools, or else as a fool in a world of wise men, when
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all men feel so sure and ever thy doubts increase. When all that spake
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with thee of thine old deeds are dead, those that saw them not shall
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: speak of them again to thee; till one speaking to thee of thy deeds of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valour add more than even a man should when speaking to a King, and thou
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shalt suddenly doubt whether these great deeds were; and there shall be
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: none to tell thee, only the echoes of the voices of the gods still
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: singing in thine ears when long ago They called the princes that were
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thy friends. And thou shalt hear the knowledge of the olden time most
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wrongly told and afterwards forgotten. Then many prophets shall arise
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: claiming discovery of that old knowledge. Then thou shalt find that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seeking knowledge is vain, as the chase is vain, as making merry is
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: vain, as all things are vain. One day thou shalt find that it is vain
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to be a King. Greatly then will the acclamations of the people weary
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thee, till the time when people grow aweary of Kings. Then thou shalt
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: know that thou hast been uprooted from thine olden time and set to live
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in uncongenial years, and jests all new to royal ears shall smite thee
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on the head like hailstones, when thou hast lost thy crown, when those
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to whose grandsires thou hadst granted to bring them as children to kiss
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the feet of the King shall mock at thee because thou hast not learnt to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: barter with gold.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Not all the marvels of the future time shall atone to thee for those
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old memories that glow warmer and brighter every year as they recede
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the ages that the gods have gathered. And always dreaming of thy
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long dead princes and of the great Kings of other kingdoms in the olden
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: time thou shalt fail to see the grandeur to which a hurrying jesting
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people shall attain in that kingless age. Lastly, O King, thou shalt
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: perceive men changing in a way that thou shalt not comprehend, knowing
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: what thou canst not know, till thou shalt discover that these are men
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: no more and a new race holds dominion over the earth whose forefathers
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were men. These shall speak to thee no more as they hurry upon a quest
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that thou shalt never understand, and thou shalt know that thou canst
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: no longer take thy part in shaping destinies, but in a world of cities
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: only pine for air and the waving grass again and the sound of a wind in
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: trees. Then even this shall end with the shapes of the gods in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: darkness gathering all lives but thine, when the hills shall fling up
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth's long stored heat back to the heavens again, when earth shall be
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old and cold, with nothing alive upon it but one King."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said the King: "Pray to those hard gods still, for those that have
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: loved the earth with all its gardens and woods and singing streams will
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: love earth still when it is old and cold and with all its gardens gone
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and all the purport of its being failed and nought but memories."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: _IX_
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then spake Paharn, a prophet of the land of Hurn.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Paharn said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "There was one man that knew, but he stands not here."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the King said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Is he further than my heralds might travel in the night if they went
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon fleet horses?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the prophet answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "He is no further than thy heralds may well travel in the night, but
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: further than they may return from in all the years. Out of this city
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there goes a valley wandering through all the world and opens out at
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: last on the green land of Hurn. On the one side in the distance gleams
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sea, and on the other side a forest, black and ancient, darkens the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fields of Hurn; beyond the forest and the sea there is no more, saving
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the twilight and beyond that the gods. In the mouth of the valley
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sleeps the village of Rhistaun.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Here I was born, and heard the murmur of the flocks and herds, and saw
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the tall smoke standing between the sky and the still roofs of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Rhistaun, and learned that men might not go into the dark forest, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that beyond the forest and the sea was nought saving the twilight, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beyond that the gods. Often there came travellers from the world all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down the winding valley, and spake with strange speech in Rhistaun and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: returned again up the valley going back to the world. Sometimes with
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bells and camels and men running on foot, Kings came down the valley
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the world, but always the travellers returned by the valley again
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and none went further than the land of Hurn.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And Kithneb also was born in the land of Hurn and tended the flocks
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with me, but Kithneb would not care to listen to the murmur of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flocks and herds and see the tall smoke standing between the roofs and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sky, but needed to know how far from Hurn it was that the world met
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the twilight, and how far across the twilight sat the gods.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And often Kithneb dreamed as he tended the flocks and herds, and when
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: others slept he would wander near to the edge of the forest wherein men
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: might not go. And the elders of the land of Hurn reproved Kithneb when
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he dreamed; yet Kithneb was still as other men and mingled with his
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fellows until the day of which I will tell thee, O King. For Kithneb
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was aged about a score of years, and he and I were sitting near the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flocks, and he gazed long at the point where the dark forest met the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sea at the end of the land of Hurn. But when night drove the twilight
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down under the forest we brought the flocks together to Rhistaun, and I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went up the street between the houses to see four princes that had come
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down the valley from the world, and they were clad in blue and scarlet
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and wore plumes upon their heads, and they gave us in exchange for our
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sheep some gleaming stones which they told us were of great value on
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the word of princes. And I sold them three sheep, and Darniag sold them
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eight.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "But Kithneb came not with the others to the market place where the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: four princes stood, but went alone across the fields to the edge of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forest.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And it was upon the next morning that the strange thing befell
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Kithneb; for I saw him in the morning coming from the fields, and I
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hailed him with the shepherd's cry wherewith we shepherds call to one
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: another, and he answered not. Then I stopped and spake to him, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Kithneb said not a word till I became angry and left him.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Then we spake together concerning Kithneb, and others had hailed him,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and he had not answered them, but to one he had said that he had heard
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the voices of the gods speaking beyond the forest and so would never
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: listen more to the voices of men.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Then we said: 'Kithneb is mad,' and none hindered him.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Another took his place among the flocks, and Kithneb sat in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evenings by the edge of the forest on the plain, alone.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "So Kithneb spake to none for many days, but when any forced him to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: speak he said that every evening he heard the gods when they came to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sit in the forest from over the twilight and sea, and that he would
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: speak no more with men.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "But as the months went by, men in Rhistaun came to look on Kithneb as
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a prophet, and we were wont to point to him when strangers came down
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the valley from the world, saying:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Here in the land of Hurn we have a prophet such as you have not among
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: your cities, for he speaks at evening with the gods.'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "A year had passed over the silence of Kithneb when he came to me and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spake. And I bowed before him because we believed that he spake among
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods. And Kithneb said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'I will speak to thee before the end because I am most lonely. For how
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: may I speak again with men and women in the little streets of Rhistaun
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among the houses, when I have heard the voices of the gods singing
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: above the twilight? But I am more lonely than ever Rhistaun wonts of,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for this I tell thee, _when I hear the gods I know not what They say_.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Well indeed I know the voice of each, for ever calling me away from
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: contentment; well I know Their voices as they call to my soul and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: trouble it; I know by Their tone when They rejoice, and I know when
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They are sad, for even the gods feel sadness. I know when over fallen
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cities of the past, and the curved white bones of heroes They sing the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dirges of the gods' lament. But alas! Their words I know not, and the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wonderful strains of the melody of Their speech beat on my soul and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pass away unknown.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Therefore I travelled from the land of Hurn till I came to the house
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the prophet Arnin-Yo, and told him that I sought to find the meaning
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the gods; and Arnin-Yo told me to ask the shepherds concerning all
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods, for what the shepherds knew it was meet for a man to know,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and, beyond that, knowledge turned into trouble.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'But I told Arnin-Yo that I had heard myself the voices of the gods
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and knew that They were there beyond the twilight and so could never
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more bow down to the gods that the shepherds made from the red clay
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: which they scooped with their hands out of the hillside.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Then said Arnin-Yo to me:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'"Natheless forget that thou hast heard the gods and bow down again to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gods of the red clay that the shepherds make, and find thereby the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ease that the shepherds find, and at last die, remembering devoutly the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods of the red clay that the shepherds scooped with their hands out of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hill. For the gifts of the gods that sit beyond the twilight and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: smile at the gods of clay, are neither ease nor contentment."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'And I said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'"The god that my mother made out of the red clay that she had got
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the hill, fashioning it with many arms and eyes as she sang me
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: songs of its power, and told me stories of its mystic birth, this god
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is lost and broken; and ever in my ears is ringing the melody of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'And Arnin-Yo said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'"If thou wouldst still seek knowledge know that only those that come
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: behind the gods may clearly know their meaning. And this thou canst
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: only do by taking ship and putting out to sea from the land of Hurn and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sailing up the coast towards the forest. There the sea cliffs turn to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the left or southward, and full upon them beats the twilight from over
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sea, and there thou mayest come round behind the forest. Here where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the world's edge mingles with the twilight the gods come in the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening, and if thou canst come behind Them thou shalt hear Their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: voices clear, beating full seaward and filling all the twilight with
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sound of song, and thou shalt know the meaning of the gods. But where
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the cliffs turn southward there sits behind the gods Brimdono, the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: oldest whirlpool in the sea, roaring to guard his masters. Him the gods
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have chained for ever to the floor of the twilit sea to guard the door
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the forest that lieth above the cliffs. Here, then, if thou canst
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hear the voices of the gods as thou hast said, thou wilt know their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: meaning clear, but this will profit thee little when Brimdono drags
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thee down and all thy ship.'"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Thus spake Kithneb to me.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "But I said:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'O Kithneb, forget those whirlpool-guarded gods beyond the forest, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: if thy small god be lost thou shalt worship with me the small god that
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: my mother made. Thousands of years ago he conquered cities but is not
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: any longer an angry god. Pray to him, Kithneb, and he shall bring thee
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: comfort and increase to thy flocks and a mild spring, and at the last a
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: quiet ending for thy days.'
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "But Kithneb heeded not, and only bade me find a fisher ship and men to
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: row it. So on the next day we put forth from the land of Hurn in a boat
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that the fisher folk use. And with us came four of the fisher folk who
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rowed the boat while I held the rudder, but Kithneb sat and spake not
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in the prow. And we rowed westward up the coast till we came at evening
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: where the cliffs turned southward and the twilight gleamed upon them
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the sea.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "There we turned southwards and saw at once Brimdono. And
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: as a man tears the purple cloak of a king slain in battle to divide it
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with other warriors,--Brimdono tore the sea. And ever around and around
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him with a gnarled hand Brimdono whirled the sail of some adventurous
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ship, the trophy of some calamity wrought in his greed for shipwreck
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long ago where he sat to guard his masters from all who fare on the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sea. And ever one far-reaching empty hand swung up and down so that we
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: durst go no nearer.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Only Kithneb neither saw Brimdono nor heard his roar, and when we
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: would go no further bade us lower a small boat with oars out of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ship. Into this boat Kithneb descended, not heeding words from us, and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: onward rowed alone. A cry of triumph over ships and men Brimdono
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: uttered before him, but Kithneb's eyes were turned toward the forest as
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he came behind the gods. Upon his face the twilight beat full from the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: haunts of evening to illumine the smiles that grew about his eyes as he
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came behind the gods. Him that had found the gods above Their twilit
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cliffs, him that had heard Their voices close at last and knew Their
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: meaning clear, him, from the cheerless world with its doubtings and
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prophets that lie, from all hidden meanings, where truth rang clear at
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: last, Brimdono took."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But when Paharn ceased to speak, in the King's ears the roar of
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Brimdono exulting over ancient triumphs and the whelming of ships
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seemed still to ring.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then Mohontis spake, the hermit prophet, who lived in the deep
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: untravelled woods that seclude Lake Ilana.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I dreamed that to the west of all the seas I saw by vision the mouth
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Munra-O, guarded by golden gates, and through the bars of the gates
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that guard the mysterious river of Munra-O I saw the flashes of golden
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: barques, wherein the gods went up and down, and to and fro through the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening dusk. And I saw that Munra-O was a river of dreams such as came
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through remembered gardens in the night, to charm our infancy as we
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slept beneath the sloping gables of the houses of long ago. And Munra-O
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the figure answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I am a prophet."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the King said: "Knowest _thou_ aught concerning the journey of the
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King?" And the figure answered: "I know, but have never said."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the King said: "Who art thou that knowest so much and has not told
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it?"
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he answered:
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I am _The End_."
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the cloaked figure strode away from the palace; and the King,
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unseen by the guards, followed upon his journey.
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE END
title: Time and the Gods
author: Dunsany, Lord
